page.title: 02HOME FARM - PARKS
page.content: The Parks at{Hutton}extend to 210 acres and abut the eastern, southern and western edges of the Hall grounds. They are split into 4 parts. The largest and most easterly, known as the 'Big Park', extends to 137 acres. It is split by the deep valley of the River Petteril and contains a number of mature trees, especially oak. A number of plantings have been carried out to replace existing trees and to provide habitats. It is used for hay, and as grazing for ewes, lambs and dairy replacements. The remaining three areas are more or less the same size and also contain park trees and again some plantings have been established. One area adjacent to the dairy unit is grazed by dairy cows, and the two others, next to the Hall, are grazed by ewes, lambs and dairy heifers.
